medium_description_en: <span id="docs-internal-guid-51426a60-7fff-1044-4feb-dfab6ce3b8c7">Predicts in-hospital survival in adult patients after VA ECMO for refractory cardiogenic shock.
short_description_en: Survival after VA ECMO for cardiogenic shock.

seo.meta_description_en: The Survival after Veno-Arterial ECMO (SAVE) Score predicts survival in adult patients after ECMO for refractory cardiogenic shock.
seo.keywords_en: Ecmo, cardiac shock, refractory cardiogenic shock, cardiogenic shock, mortality, risk

how_to_use.use_case_en:
• Patients with refractory cardiogenic shock in whom veno-arterial (VA) ECMO is being considered.

  • Do not use in patients receiving veno-venous (VV) ECMO (see RESP Score).
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Only predicts survival to hospital discharge and does not predict neurologic function or functional status, which may be important considerations.

  • The score was derived from a cohort of patients who were placed on VA ECMO, and likely excluded many patients who may have had different survival rates.

  • Patients receiving CPR during cannulation (eCPR) were not included in the derivation of the SAVE Score; therefore, the score may not apply to these patients.
how_to_use.why_use_en: ECMO is a resource-intensive endeavor with high morbidity, and patients should be selected carefully. Survival estimates may aid the decision process.

next_steps.advice_en: Other factors may contribute to the decision to initiate ECMO (e.g. life expectancy, quality of life, resource availability).
next_steps.management_en: We are not aware of any guidelines that incorporate the SAVE Score, but survival prediction may be incorporated into the decision to initiate VA ECMO.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: Comprehensive decision-making should not be based solely on one prediction rule, and the threshold to initiate ECMO may vary by institution.

about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
The SAVE Score was derived by Schmidt et al (2015) in a retrospective cohort study of 3,846 patients in the ELSO registry who received VA ECMO primarily for cardiogenic shock. The following patients were excluded:

  • Patients receiving ECMO during CPR.

  • Patients not receiving VA ECMO.

  • Patients with primary diagnosis of respiratory failure (n = 117).

  • Patients not on first run of ECMO (n = 165).

The outcome measured was survival to hospital discharge (see Facts & Figures above).

Schmidt et al (2015) also prospectively validated the SAVE Score in 161 patients receiving VA ECMO primarily for cardiogenic shock from a single institution from July 2006 to Dec 2013. 108 patients survived to hospital discharge (67%) and 53 patients died (33%). Patients with primary respiratory failure (n = 7) and insufficient data (n = 12) were excluded. The prediction rule performed with c = 0.90 and Hosmer-Lemeshow C-statistic of 13.97 (p = 0.08). The validation cohort was small, and was not compared to patients not receiving VA ECMO.

Chen et al (2016) further validated the SAVE Score in a retrospective analysis of 154 patients receiving ECMO within 24 hrs of ED arrival and found an AUC of 0.73 when lactate was added to the SAVE Score.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Schmidt M, Burrell A, Roberts L, et al. Predicting survival after ECMO for refractory cardiogenic shock: the survival after veno-arterial-ECMO (SAVE)-score. Eur Heart J. 2015;36(33):2246-56.

Validation.text: Chen WC, Huang KY, Yao CW, et al. The modified SAVE score: predicting survival using urgent veno-arterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation within 24 hours of arrival at the emergency department. Crit Care. 2016;20(1):336.

expert_name.description: Christopher Tainter, MD, RDMS, is an intensivist and emergency physician at the University of California, San Diego. Raised in Seattle, Dr. Tainter received his medical degree from the University of Washington School of Medicine. He then completed an emergency medicine residency at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City, and a fellowship in anesthesia critical care medicine at the Massachusetts General Hospital. He is the fellowship director for UCSD's emergency medicine/anesthesia critical care medicine fellowship program.
expert_name.name: Christopher Tainter, MD, RDMS

creator_info.about_en: Matthieu Schmidt, MD, PhD, is an assistant professor in Sorbonne Université and in medical intensive care at the Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital in Paris, France. With more than 100 peer-review publications referenced in PubMed, Dr. Schmidt’s primary research is focused on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, severe acute respiratory distress syndrome, patient-ventilator interactions, and refractory cardiogenic shock.
